In [[telecommunications]] an '''aerial insert''' is a segment of [[Telephone cable|cabling]] that rises from ground to a point above ground, followed by an overhead run, e.g. on poles, followed by a drop back into the ground. An aerial insert is used in places where it is not possible or practical to place a cable underground. Aerial inserts might be encountered in crossing deep [[ditch]]es, [[canal]]s, [[river]]s, or [[Subway (rail)|subway lines]].<ref>[http://www.its.bldrdoc.gov/fs-1037/other/a.pdf Federal Standard 1037C]</ref>

'''Antipasto''' (plural '''antipasti''') is the traditional first course of a formal [[Meal structure in Italy|Italian meal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/antipasto|title=Definition of ANTIPASTO|website=www.merriam-webster.com}}</ref> Typical ingredients of a traditional antipasto include [[cured meat]]s, [[olive]]s, [[peperoncini]], [[edible mushroom|mushrooms]], [[Anchovy|anchovies]], [[artichoke]] hearts, various [[cheese]]s (such as [[provolone]] or [[mozzarella]]), pickled meats, and vegetables in oil or vinegar.
The contents of an antipasto vary greatly according to regional cuisine. It is quite possible to find different preparations of saltwater fish and traditional southern cured meats (like [[soppressata]] or [['nduja]]) in the [[southern Italy|south of Italy]], whereas in [[northern Italy]] it will contain different kinds of cured meats and mushrooms and, especially near lakes, preparations of [[freshwater fish]]. The cheeses included also vary significantly between regions and backgrounds, and include hard and soft cheeses.
Many compare antipasto to [[hors d'oeuvre]], but antipasto is served at the table and signifies the official beginning of the [[Italy|Italian]] meal. It may also be referred to as a starter, or an [[appetizer]].

The company used [[Chemical vapor deposition of diamond|chemical vapor deposition]] (CVD) for the production of their gem-sized [[synthetic diamond]] crystals, and obtained several U.S. [[patent]]s on the process. The '''Baku–Batumi pipeline''' is the name given to several [[Pipeline transport|pipelines]] and pipeline projects to transport [[kerosene]] and [[crude oil]] from the [[Caspian region]] to the [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] [[Batumi]] oil terminal at the [[Black Sea]]. When first constructed in 1906, it was the world's longest kerosene pipeline.<ref name=transnefteprodukt/>
==Kerosene pipeline== Together with oil developments in the Baku area, the need for construction of the oil pipeline from Baku to the Black Sea rose. The first pipeline proposal was submitted by Russian engineer I. Ilimov already in 1878.<ref name=transnefteprodukt> {{cite web | url= http://eng.transnefteprodukt.ru/news/news126.html | title=From Field to Trunk Pipelines | publisher=[[Transnefteproduct]] | accessdate=2008-07-12 }} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> In 1880, [[Dmitri Mendeleev]] proposed the construction of Baku–Batum pipeline to ensure the transportation of Baku oil to the world market.<ref name=az> {{cite web | url= http://www.azerbaijan.az/_Economy/_OilStrategy/oilStrategy_02_e.html | title=History of development of oil industry | publisher=Azerbaijan Portal | accessdate=2008-07-18 }}</ref> In 1884, the chief engineer [[Vladimir Shukhov]] of Bari engineering company published a scientifically based draft and estimate of the Baku – Batum oil pipeline. Also the pipeline technical project was later designed by Vladimir Shukhov. In 1885, mining engineer I. Ilimov established the Caspian and Black Sea Oil Pipeline company. In December 1887, the Government of Russia granted to Ilimov the concession to establish the Society of the Caspian-Black Sea Oil Pipeline, a [[joint stock company]]. However, in 1891 the pipeline construction was postponed as premature, and the construction started only in 1896. At the first stage, the Batum-Mikhailovo (Khashuri) section was constructed, while the construction of Baku-Mikhailovo (Khashuri) section was finished only in 1906 [ref.11].<ref name=transneft1> {{cite journal |url=http://www.transneft.ru/About/History/Default.asp?LANG=EN |title=Russian pipeline transport (1860-1917) |author1=A.M. Shammazov |author2=B.N. Mastobajev |author3=A. Soshchenko |journal=Truboprovodny transport nefti (Oil Pipelines) |publisher=[[Transneft]] |issue=6 |year=2000 |accessdate=2008-07-12 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080515230435/http://www.transneft.ru/About/History/Default.asp?LANG=EN |archivedate=2008-05-15 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The first pipeline was kerosene pipeline with total length of {{convert|835|km|mi}} and 16 pumping stations. The diameter of the pipeline was mainly {{convert|8|in|mm|-1}}, but some parts had diameter of {{convert|10|in|mm|-1}} and {{convert|12|in|mm|-1}}.<ref name=transneft1/> The pipes were produced at plants in [[Mariupol]], Sosnovtsa and Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipro]]).<ref name=transnefteprodukt/> The pipeline was built along the railroad line and the telephone communication was arranged along the route. The initial pipeline capacity was 980,000 tons of kerosene per annum. Pumping stations were equipped with plunger pumps, driven by steam and [[diesel engine]]s.<ref name=transneft1/> The pipeline for its time was the longest pipeline in the world.<ref name=transnefteprodukt/>
After the [[October Revolution|Bolshevik Revolution]], kerosene deliveries through the pipeline were relaunched in March 1921 and on 20 May 1921, the first delivery of kerosene arrived at Batum. After 1936 Batum was renamed to Batumi [ref.11].<ref name=transneft2> {{cite journal|url=http://www.transneft.ru/About/History/Default.asp?LANG=EN&ID=343 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030502111419/http://www.transneft.ru/About/History/Default.asp?LANG=EN&ID=343 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2003-05-02 |title=History. Truboprovodny transport Rossii (1946-91) |author1=A.M. Shammazov |author2=B.N. Mastobajev |author3=R.N. Bakhtizin |journal=Truboprovodny transport nefti (Oil Pipelines) |publisher=[[Transneft]] |issue=2 |year=2001 |accessdate=2008-07-12 |format= }}</ref>
==Crude oil pipeline== The project of new pipeline was proposed in 1924. In 1925, the [[Soviet Union]] held negotiations with French companies to set up a joint venture to construct and operate the Baku-Batum crude oil pipeline. The intention was to use the pipeline for oil export to Europe, mainly to [[France]]. However, the negotiations failed as also failed negotiations with the United States companies. In 1927, the construction of the pipeline was awarded to Azneft, an [[Oil industry in Azerbaijan|Azerbaijani]] oil company. The project designer and construction manager was A.V. Bulgakov.<ref name=lukoil1/>
The construction started in May 1928 and the pipeline was opened on 30 April 1930. It supplied mainly Batum's refinery.<ref name=lukoil1> {{Cite journal | last =Mishin | first =Vladimir | title =Breaking through the oil blockade | journal = Oil of Russia | publisher = [[Lukoil]] | issue = 23 | year =2005 | url= http://www.oilru.com/or/24/415/ | accessdate =2008-07-12 }}</ref>
The crude oil pipeline had a diameter of {{convert|10|in|mm|-1}} and the length was {{convert|834|km|mi}}.<ref name=transneft2/> The pipeline had 13 pumping stations each equipped with three diesel pumps of 360 [[Horsepower|hp]]. The pipeline used over 60,000 German-manufactured pipes weighing a total of over 54,000 tons. Diesels for the pipeline were purchased from [[MAN SE|MAN AG]], pumps from [[Crossley]] and generators from [[Theodor Bergmann]].<ref name=lukoil1/> Construction work was done on three sections simultaneously. The highest point was at the {{convert|823|m|ft}} above of [[sea level]]. The first {{convert|21|km|mi}} long section Mikhailovo (Khashuri)-Batum was completed on 13 February 1929, the second {{convert|363|km|mi}} long section Mingechaur-Mikhailovo (Khashuri) was completed on 15 December 1929, and the third {{convert|248|km|mi}} long section Baku-Mingechaur was completed on 13 February 1930. The pipeline cost 49 million rubles.<ref name=lukoil1/>
The operation of the oil pipeline showed that it was incapable of transporting oil in planned amount and the capacity was needed to increase by 750,000 tons.<ref name=transneft2/> In August 1942, the pipeline was dismantled in connection with the threat of penetration of German troops in that direction and its pipes were used for the construction of the [[Astrakhan]]-[[Saratov]] pipeline.<ref name=transnefteprodukt/> In 1990s, some part of the pipeline were used for the construction of the [[Baku-Supsa Pipeline]].
==New pipeline== There have been several proposals for the new Baku–Batumi pipeline. In 1994-1998, the Baku-Supsa Pipeline, which partly uses old Baku–Batum pipeline route, was constructed. On 2 March 1998, [[Chevron Corporation]] agreed to reconstruct existing Khashuri-Batumi pipeline and construct [[Dubandi]] (Baku)- Khashuri pipeline.<ref name=cbr>{{cite journal |url = http://ourworld.compuserve.com/HOMEPAGES/USAZERB/980315c.htm |title = Caspian Business Report |publisher = US-Azerbaijan Council |volume = 2 |issue = 5 |date = 1998-03-15 |accessdate = 2008-07-12 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080212074130/http://ourworld.compuserve.com/HOMEPAGES/USAZERB/980315c.htm |archivedate = 2008-02-12 |deadurl = yes |df = |journal = }}</ref> However, in May 2001 Chevron canceled this project and started to ship its oil from [[Tengiz Field]] through the [[Caspian Pipeline Consortium|CPC pipeline]].<ref name=export> {{cite web | url= http://www.aghayan.com/caspoilx0702.htm | title=Caspian Sea Region: Oil Export Options | publisher=Dr. Alexander Aghayan & Associates, Inc. | date=July 2002 | accessdate=2008-07-12 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080615185738/http://www.aghayan.com/caspoilx0702.htm| archivedate= 15 June 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Kazakhstan's national oil company [[KazMunayGas]], owner of the Batumi Oil Terminal, has shown interest to build the new Baku–Batumi pipeline, which together with proposed [[Trans-Caspian Oil Pipeline|Trans-Caspian]] and Batumi-[[Constanţa]] connections would allow to supply KazMunayGas [[Oil refinery|oil refineries]] in Romania ([[Rompetrol]]) and planned refinery in Batumi.<ref name=trend1> {{Cite news | title = Way to Europe May Lie via Baku-Batumi- Constants: Head of Rompetrol | publisher = Trend News | date =2008-02-09 | url= http://capital.trendaz.com/?show=news&newsid=1131493&catid=519&subcatid=481&lang=EN | accessdate =2008-07-12 }}</ref><ref name=trend2> {{Cite news | title = Kazakhstan Interested in Oil Delivery via Baku-Susa Pipeline: Diplomat | publisher = Trend News | date =2008-07-09 | url= http://news.trendaz.com/?show=news&newsid=1242782&lang=EN | accessdate =2008-07-12 }}</ref><ref name=trend3> {{Cite news | title = Kazakhstan Negotiates with Azerbaijan and Georgia to Construct New Oil Pipeline | author = K. Konirova | publisher = Trend News | date =2008-07-07 | url= http://capital.trendaz.com/?show=news&newsid=1240605&catid=519&subcatid=481&lang=EN | accessdate =2008-07-12 }}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Azerbaijan|Georgia (country)|Energy}} * [[Energy in Georgia (country)]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}} Mir-Babayev M.F. Pipeline transportation in the Baku oil industry (dedicated to the 115th anniversary of commencing the construction of unique pipeline Baku-Batum) – “Azerbaijan Oil Industry”, 2012, #1, p. 63-69

{{Sustainable energy}} '''Carbon-neutral fuel''' is energy fuel or energy systems which have no net greenhouse gas emissions or carbon footprint. One class is [[synthetic fuel]] (including [[methane]], [[gasoline]], [[diesel fuel]], [[jet fuel]] or [[Ammonia#As a fuel|ammonia]])<ref>Leighty and Holbrook (2012) [http://www.intpowertechcorp.com/ASME-IMECE-12-87097-FINAL-30Jul12-C.pdf "Running the World on Renewables: Alternatives for Trannd Low-cost Firming Storage of Stranded Renewable as Hydrogen and Ammonia Fuels via Underground Pipelines"] ''Proceedings of the ASME 2012 International Mechanical Engineering Congress & Exposition'' November 9–15, 2012, Houston, Texas</ref> produced from [[renewable energy|renewable]], [[sustainable energy|sustainable]] or [[nuclear power|nuclear energy]] used to [[hydrogenation|hydrogenate]] [[carbon dioxide]] directly captured from the air (DAC), recycled from [[flue-gas emissions from fossil-fuel combustion|power plant flue]] [[exhaust gas]] or derived from [[carbonic acid]] in [[seawater]]. [[Renewable energy]] sources include wind turbines, solar panels, and hydroelectric power stations.<!-- 1--><ref name=Zeman2008>{{Cite journal |last=Zeman |first=Frank S. |last2=Keith |first2=David W. |date=2008 |title=Carbon neutral hydrocarbons |journal=[[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A]] |volume=366 |issue=1882 |pages=3901–18 |doi=10.1098/rsta.2008.0143 |pmid=18757281 |url=http://www.keith.seas.harvard.edu/papers/103.Zeman.2008.CHNCs.e.pdf |accessdate=September 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130525135837/http://www.keith.seas.harvard.edu/papers/103.Zeman.2008.CHNCs.e.pdf |archivedate=May 25, 2013 |df= }} (Review.)</ref><!-- 2--><ref name=Wang2012>{{Cite journal |last=Wang |first=Wei |last2=Wang |first2=Shengping |last3=Ma |first3=Xinbin |last4=Gong |first4=Jinlong |date=2011 |title=Recent advances in catalytic hydrogenation of carbon dioxide |journal=Chemical Society Reviews |volume=40 |issue=7 |pages=3703–27 |doi=10.1039/C1CS15008A |pmid=21505692 |url=http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlelanding/2011/cs/c1cs15008a |accessdate=July 6, 2013|citeseerx=10.1.1.666.7435 }} (Review.)</ref><!-- 3--><ref name=MacDowell2010>{{Cite journal |last=MacDowell |first=Niall |date=2010 |title=An overview of CO<sub>2</sub> capture technologies |journal=Energy and Environmental Science |volume=3 |issue=11 |pages=1645–69 |doi=10.1039/C004106H |url=http://pubs.rsc.org/en/Content/ArticleLanding/2010/EE/c004106h |accessdate=September 7, 2012|display-authors=etal}} (Review.)</ref><!-- 4--><ref name=Eisaman2012>{{Cite journal |last=Eisaman |first=Matthew D. |date=2012 |title=CO<sub>2</sub> extraction from seawater using bipolar membrane electrodialysis |journal=Energy and Environmental Science |volume=5 |issue=6 |pages=7346–52 |doi=10.1039/C2EE03393C |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/237005785 |accessdate=July 6, 2013 |display-authors=etal|citeseerx=10.1.1.698.8497 }}</ref><!-- --> Another type of renewable energy source is [[biofuel]]<ref>[https://www.eia.gov/energyexplained/print.php?page=biomass_environment Biomass and the Environment – Basics]</ref>. Such fuels are potentially [[carbon-neutral]] because they do not result in a net increase in atmospheric [[greenhouse gas]]es.<!-- 5--><ref name=Graves2011rev>{{Cite journal |last=Graves |first=Christopher |last2=Ebbesen |first2=Sune D. |last3=Mogensen |first3=Mogens |last4=Lackner |first4=Klaus S. |date=2011 |title=Sustainable hydrocarbon fuels by recycling CO<sub>2</sub> and H<sub>2</sub>O with renewable or nuclear energy |journal=Renewable and Sustainable Energy Reviews |volume=15 |issue=1 |pages=1–23 |doi=10.1016/j.rser.2010.07.014|url=http://orbit.dtu.dk/en/publications/sustainable-hydrocarbon-fuels-by-recycling-co2-and-h2o-with-renewable-or-nuclear-energy(4cc6e93b-c64e-477c-80b1-b5a9677ffec7).html }} (Review.)</ref><!-- 6--><ref name=Socolow2011>{{Cite report |last=Socolow |first=Robert |date=June 1, 2011 |title=''Direct Air Capture of CO<sub>2</sub> with Chemicals: A Technology Assessment for the APS Panel on Public Affairs'' |publisher=American Physical Society |type=peer reviewed literature review |url=http://www.aps.org/policy/reports/assessments/upload/dac2011.pdf |accessdate=September 7, 2012|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>[http://www.co2-chemistry.eu/ Conference on Carbon Dioxide as Feedstock for Chemistry and Polymers] (Essen, Germany, October 10–11, 2012; [http://www.co2-chemistry.eu/media/files/journal/12-10-01ConferenceJournal.pdf post-conference program])</ref>
To the extent that carbon-neutral fuels displace [[fossil fuel]]s, or if they are produced from waste carbon or seawater carbonic acid, and their combustion is subject to [[carbon capture]] at the flue or exhaust pipe, they result in [[negative carbon dioxide emission]] and net [[carbon dioxide removal]] from the atmosphere, and thus constitute a form of [[greenhouse gas remediation]].<!-- 7--><ref name=Goeppert2012>{{Cite journal |last=Goeppert |first=Alain |last2=Czaun |first2=Miklos |last3=Prakash |first3=G.K. Surya |last4=Olah |first4=George A. |date=2012 |title=Air as the renewable carbon source of the future: an overview of CO<sub>2</sub> capture from the atmosphere |journal=Energy and Environmental Science |volume=5 |issue=7 |pages=7833–53 |doi=10.1039/C2EE21586A |url=http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlelanding/2012/ee/c2ee21586a |accessdate=September 7, 2012}} (Review.)</ref><!-- 8--><ref name=House2011>{{cite journal |last=House |first=K.Z. |last2=Baclig |first2=A.C. |last3=Ranjan |first3=M. |last4=van Nierop |first4=E.A. |last5=Wilcox |first5=J. |last6=Herzog |first6=H.J. |title=Economic and energetic analysis of capturing CO<sub>2</sub> from ambient air |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |volume=108 |issue=51 |date=2011 |pages=20428–33 |doi=10.1073/pnas.1012253108 |pmid=22143760 |url=http://sequestration.mit.edu/pdf/1012253108full.pdf |accessdate=September 7, 2012|pmc=3251141 }} (Review.)</ref><!-- 9--><ref name=Lackner2012>{{Cite journal |last=Lackner |first=Klaus S. |date=2012 |title=The urgency of the development of CO<sub>2</sub> capture from ambient air |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America |volume=109 |issue=33 |pages=13156–62 |doi=10.1073/pnas.1108765109 |url=http://www.pnas.org/content/109/33/13156.abstract |accessdate=September 7, 2012 |pmid=22843674|display-authors=etal |pmc=3421162}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kothandaraman|first=Jotheeswari|last2=Goeppert|first2=Alain|last3=Czaun|first3=Miklos|last4=Olah|first4=George A.|last5=Prakash|first5=G. K. Surya|date=2016-01-27|title=Conversion of CO2 from Air into Methanol Using a Polyamine and a Homogeneous Ruthenium Catalyst|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|volume=138|issue=3|pages=778–781|doi=10.1021/jacs.5b12354|pmid=26713663|issn=0002-7863}}</ref>
Such [[power to gas]] carbon-neutral and '''carbon-negative fuels''' can be produced by the [[electrolysis of water]] to make [[hydrogen]] used in the [[Sabatier reaction]] to produce methane which may then be [[Power storage#Synthetic hydrocarbon fuel|stored]] to be burned later in [[natural gas power plant|power plants]] as synthetic [[natural gas]], transported by pipeline, truck, or tanker ship, or be used in [[gas to liquids]] processes such as the [[Fischer–Tropsch process]] to make traditional fuels for transportation or heating.<!-- 10--><ref name=Pearson2012>{{Cite journal|last=Pearson |first=R.J. |last2=Eisaman |first2=M.D. |date=2012 |title=Energy Storage via Carbon-Neutral Fuels Made From CO<sub>2</sub>, Water, and Renewable Energy |journal=Proceedings of the IEEE |volume=100 |issue=2 |pages=440–60 |doi=10.1109/JPROC.2011.2168369 |url=http://www.uk-shec.org.uk/uk-shec/news/IEEE_Paper_6_3_5_finalx1x.pdf |accessdate=September 7, 2012 |display-authors=etal |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130508220516/http://www.uk-shec.org.uk/uk-shec/news/IEEE_Paper_6_3_5_finalx1x.pdf |archivedate=May 8, 2013 |df= |citeseerx=10.1.1.359.8746 }} (Review.)</ref><!-- 11--><ref name=Pennline2010>{{Cite journal |last=Pennline |first=Henry W. |date=2010 |title=Separation of CO<sub>2</sub> from flue gas using electrochemical cells |journal=Fuel |volume=89 |issue=6 |pages=1307–14 |doi=10.1016/j.fuel.2009.11.036|display-authors=etal}}</ref><!-- 12--><ref name=Graves2011cells>{{Cite journal |last=Graves |first=Christopher |last2=Ebbesen |first2=Sune D. |last3=Mogensen |first3=Mogens |date=2011 |title=Co-electrolysis of CO<sub>2</sub> and H<sub>2</sub>O in solid oxide cells: Performance and durability |journal=Solid State Ionics |volume=192 |issue=1 |pages=398–403 |doi=10.1016/j.ssi.2010.06.014}}</ref>
Carbon-neutral fuels are used in Germany and Iceland for [[Power storage#Synthetic hydrocarbon fuel|distributed storage of renewable energy]], minimizing problems of wind and solar intermittency, and enabling transmission of wind, water, and solar power through existing natural gas pipelines. Such [[renewable fuels]] could alleviate the costs and dependency issues of imported fossil fuels without requiring either electrification of the vehicle fleet or conversion to hydrogen or other fuels, enabling continued compatible and affordable vehicles.<ref name=Pearson2012/> A 250 kilowatt synthetic methane plant has been built in Germany and it is being scaled up to 10 megawatts.<ref>{{Cite web |author=Fraunhofer-Gesellschaft |date=May 5, 2010 |title=Storing green electricity as natural gas |publisher=''fraunhofer.de'' |url=http://www.fraunhofer.de/en/press/research-news/2010/04/green-electricity-storage-gas.html |accessdate=September 9, 2012}}</ref>
==Production== Carbon-neutral fuels are synthetic hydrocarbons. They can be produced in chemical reactions between carbon dioxide, which can be captured from power plants or the air, and hydrogen, which is created by the electrolysis of water using renewable energy. The fuel, often referred to as [[electrofuel]], stores the energy that was used in the production of the hydrogen.<ref name=Pearson>{{cite journal|last=Pearson |first=Richard |author2=Eisaman |title=Energy Storage Via Carbon-Neutral Fuels Made From Carbon dioxide, Water, and Renewable Energy |journal=Proceedings of the IEEE |date=2011 |url=http://www.uk-shec.org.uk/uk-shec/news/IEEE_Paper_6_3_5_finalx1x.pdf |accessdate=18 October 2012 |doi=10.1109/jproc.2011.2168369 |volume=100 |issue=2 |pages=440–460 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130508220516/http://www.uk-shec.org.uk/uk-shec/news/IEEE_Paper_6_3_5_finalx1x.pdf |archivedate=8 May 2013 |df= |citeseerx=10.1.1.359.8746 }}</ref> Coal can also be used to produce the hydrogen, but that would not be a carbon-neutral source. Carbon dioxide can be captured and buried, making fossil fuels carbon-neutral, although not renewable. Carbon capture from exhaust gas can make carbon-neutral fuels carbon negative. Other hydrocarbons can be broken down to produce hydrogen and carbon dioxide which could then be stored while the hydrogen is used for energy or fuel, which would also be carbon-neutral.<ref name=Kleiner>{{cite journal |last=Kleiner |first=kurt |title=Carbon Neutral Fuel; a new approach |journal=The Globe and Mail |date=17 January 2009 |pages=F4 |url=http://www.lexisnexis.com/hottopics/lnacademic/?verb=sr&csi=303830&sr=HLEAD(CARBON-NEUTRAL+FUEL)+and+date+is+January+17%2C+2009 |accessdate=23 October 2012}}</ref>
The most energy-efficient fuel to produce is [[hydrogen]] gas,<ref name ="ubaposition">{{cite web |url=https://www.umweltbundesamt.de/sites/default/files/medien/377/publikationen/uba_position_powertoliquid_engl.pdf |title =Integration of Power to Gas/Power to Liquids into the ongoing transformation process |date = June 2016|accessdate = August 10, 2017 |page =12}}</ref> which can be used in hydrogen fuel cell vehicles, and which requires the fewest process steps to produce.
Methanol can be made from a chemical reaction of a carbon-dioxide molecule with three hydrogen molecules to produce methanol and water. The stored energy can be recovered by burning the methanol in a combustion engine, releasing carbon dioxide, water, and heat. [[Methane]] can be produced in a similar reaction. Special precautions against methane leaks are important since methane is nearly 100 times as potent as CO<sub>2</sub>, in terms of [[Global warming potential]]. More energy can be used to combine methanol or methane into larger hydrocarbon fuel molecules.<ref name=Pearson2012 />
Researchers have also suggested using methanol to produce [[dimethyl ether]]. This fuel could be used as a substitute for diesel fuel due to its ability to self ignite under high pressure and temperature. It is already being used in some areas for heating and energy generation. It is nontoxic, but must be stored under pressure.<ref name=Olah>{{cite journal |last=Olah |first=George |author2=Alain Geoppert |author3=G. K. Surya Prakash |title=Chemical recycling of Carbon Dioxide to Methanol and Dimethyl Ether: From Greenhouse Gas to Renewable, Environmentally Carbon Neutral Fuels and Synthetic Hydrocarbons |journal=Journal of Organic Chemistry |date=2009 |volume=74 |issue=2 |pages=487–98 |doi=10.1021/jo801260f |pmid=19063591|citeseerx=10.1.1.629.6092 }}</ref> Larger hydrocarbons<ref name ="ubaposition"/> and [[ethanol]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.lanzatech.com/innovation/technical-overview/ | title=Technical Overview}}</ref> can also be produced from carbon dioxide and hydrogen.
All synthetic hydrocarbons are generally produced at temperatures of 200–300 °C, and at pressures of 20 to 50 bar. [[Catalyst]]s are usually used to improve the efficiency of the reaction and create the desired type of hydrocarbon fuel. Such reactions are exothermic and use about 3 mol of hydrogen per mole of carbon dioxide involved. They also produce large amounts of water as a byproduct.<ref name=Zeman2008 />
== Sources of carbon for recycling == The most economical source of carbon for recycling into fuel is [[flue-gas emissions from fossil-fuel combustion]] where it can be obtained for about USD $7.50 per ton.<ref name=MacDowell2010/><ref name=Socolow2011/><ref name= Pennline2010/> Automobile exhaust gas capture has also been seen as economical but would require extensive design changes or retrofitting.<ref name=Musadi2011>{{Cite journal |last=Musadi |first=M.R. |last2=Martin |first2=P. |last3=Garforth |first3=A. |last4=Mann |first4=R. |date=2011 |title=Carbon neutral gasoline re-synthesised from on-board sequestrated CO<sub>2</sub> |journal=Chemical Engineering Transactions |volume=24 |pages=1525–30 |doi=10.3303/CET1124255 |url=http://www.aidic.it/cet/11/24/255.pdf |accessdate=September 7, 2012}}</ref> Since carbonic acid in seawater is in [[chemical equilibrium]] with atmospheric carbon dioxide, extraction of carbon from seawater has been studied.<ref>{{Cite report |last=DiMascio |first=Felice |last2=Willauer |first2=Heather D. |authorlink2=Heather Willauer |last3=Hardy |first3=Dennis R. |last4=Lewis |first4=M. Kathleen |last5=Williams |first5=Frederick W. |date=July 23, 2010 |title=''Extraction of Carbon Dioxide from Seawater by an Electrochemical Acidification Cell. Part 1 – Initial Feasibility Studies'' |publisher=Chemistry Division, Navy Technology Center for Safety and Survivability, U.S. Naval Research Laboratory |location=Washington, DC |type=memorandum report |url=http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?Location=U2&doc=GetTRDoc.pdf&AD=ADA544002 |accessdate=September 7, 2012}}</ref><ref name= Willauer2011>{{Cite report |last=Willauer |first=Heather D. |last2=DiMascio |first2=Felice |last3=Hardy |first3=Dennis R. |last4=Lewis |first4=M. Kathleen |last5=Williams |first5=Frederick W. |date=April 11, 2011 |title=''Extraction of Carbon Dioxide from Seawater by an Electrochemical Acidification Cell. Part 2 – Laboratory Scaling Studies'' |publisher=Chemistry Division, Navy Technology Center for Safety and Survivability, U.S. Naval Research Laboratory |location=Washington, DC |type=memorandum report |url=http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?Location=U2&doc=GetTRDoc.pdf&AD=ADA544072 |accessdate=September 7, 2012}}</ref> Researchers have estimated that carbon extraction from seawater would cost about $50 per ton.<ref name=Eisaman2012/> [[Carbon dioxide air capture|Carbon capture from ambient air]] is more costly, at between $94 and $232 per ton and is considered impractical for fuel synthesis or carbon sequestration.<ref name="KeithHolmes2018">{{cite journal|last1=Keith|first1=David W.|last2=Holmes|first2=Geoffrey|last3=St. Angelo|first3=David|last4=Heidel|first4=Kenton|title=A Process for Capturing CO2 from the Atmosphere|journal=Joule|volume=2|issue=8|pages=1573–1594|year=2018|doi=10.1016/j.joule.2018.05.006}}</ref> Direct air capture is less developed than other methods. Proposals for this method involve using a caustic chemical to react with carbon dioxide in the air to produce [[carbonate]]s. These can then be broken down and hydrated to release pure CO<sub>2</sub> gas and regenerate the caustic chemical. This process requires more energy than other methods because carbon dioxide is at much lower concentrations in the atmosphere than in other sources.<ref name=Pearson2012 />
Researchers have also suggested using biomass as a carbon source for fuel production. Adding hydrogen to the biomass would reduce its carbon to produce fuel. This method has the advantage of using plant matter to cheaply capture carbon dioxide. The plants also add some chemical energy to the fuel from biological molecules. This may be a more efficient use of biomass than conventional [[biofuel]] because it uses most of the carbon and chemical energy from the biomass instead of releasing as much energy and carbon. Its main disadvantage is, as with conventional ethanol production, it competes with food production.<ref name=Zeman2008 />
{{Green economics sidebar}}
== Renewable and nuclear energy costs ==
Nighttime [[wind power]] is considered the most economical form of electrical power with which to synthesize fuel, because the [[load curve]] for electricity peaks sharply during the warmest hours of the day, but wind tends to blow slightly more at night than during the day. Therefore, the price of nighttime wind power is often much less expensive than any alternative. Off-peak wind power prices in high wind penetration areas of the U.S. averaged 1.64 cents per [[kilowatt-hour]] in 2009, but only 0.71 cents/kWh during the least expensive six hours of the day.<ref name=Pearson2012/> Typically, [[wholesale]] electricity costs 2 to 5 cents/kWh during the day.<ref>[http://www.newfuelist.com/ Electricity Price] ''NewFuelist.com'' (compare to [http://dotyenergy.com/Images/windprice-2010-W.jpg off-peak wind power price graph.]) Retrieved September 7, 2012.</ref> Commercial fuel synthesis companies suggest they can produce gasoline for less than [[petroleum]] fuels when oil costs more than $55 per barrel.<ref>{{Cite conference |last=Holte |first=Laura L. |last2=Doty |first2=Glenn N. |last3=McCree |first3=David L. |last4=Doty |first4=Judy M. |last5=Doty |first5=F. David |date=2010 |title=Sustainable Transportation Fuels From Off-peak Wind Energy, CO<sub>2</sub> and Water |conference=4th International Conference on Energy Sustainability, May 17–22, 2010 |location=Phoenix, Arizona |publisher=American Society of Mechanical Engineers |url=http://dotyenergy.com/PDFs/Doty-90366-TransportFuels-ASME-ES10.pdf |accessdate=September 7, 2012}}</ref>
In 2010, a team of process chemists led by [[Heather Willauer]] of the U.S. Navy, estimates that 100 megawatts of electricity can produce 41,000 gallons of [[jet fuel]] per day and shipboard production from nuclear power would cost about $6 per gallon. While that was about twice the petroleum fuel cost in 2010, it is expected to be much less than the market price in less than five years if recent trends continue. Moreover, since the delivery of fuel to a [[carrier battle group]] costs about $8 per gallon, shipboard production is already much less expensive.<ref name="jetsea">{{Cite report |last=Willauer |first=Heather D. |last2=Hardy |first2=Dennis R. |last3=Williams |first3=Frederick W. |date=September 29, 2010 |title=''Feasibility and Current Estimated Capital Costs of Producing Jet Fuel at Sea'' |publisher=Chemistry Division, Navy Technology Center for Safety and Survivability, U.S. Naval Research Laboratory |location=Washington, DC |type=memorandum report |url=http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?Location=U2&doc=GetTRDoc.pdf&AD=ADA539765 |accessdate=September 7, 2012}}</ref>
Willauer said seawater is the "best option" for a source of synthetic jet fuel.<ref name=Tozer2014>{{cite web |first=Jessica L. |last=Tozer |title=Energy Independence: Creating Fuel from Seawater |date=April 11, 2014 |work=Armed with Science |publisher=U.S. Department of Defense}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/innovation-works/guess-what-could-fuel-the-battleships-of-the-future-20131213 |title=Guess What Could Fuel the Battleships of the Future? |last=Koren |first=Marina |date=December 13, 2013 |journal=National Journal }}</ref> By April 2014, Willauer's team had not yet made fuel to the standard required by military jets,<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.defenseone.com/technology/2014/04/navy-just-turned-seawater-jet-fuel/82300/ |title=The Navy Just Turned Seawater Into Jet Fuel |date=April 10, 2014 |last=Tucker |first=Patrick |journal=Defense One}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/apr/10/game-changer-us-navy-can-now-turn-seawater-jet-fue/ |title=U.S. Navy to turn seawater into jet fuel |date=April 10, 2014 |last=Ernst |first=Douglas |newspaper=The Washington Times}}</ref> but they were able in September 2013 to use the fuel to fly a radio-controlled model airplane powered by a common two-stroke internal combustion engine.<ref name=Parry2014>{{cite news |url=http://www.nrl.navy.mil/media/news-releases/2014/scale-model-wwii-craft-takes-flight-with-fuel-from-the-sea-concept |title=Scale Model WWII Craft Takes Flight With Fuel From the Sea Concept |last=Parry |first=Daniel |date=April 7, 2014 |work=Naval Research Laboratory News }}</ref> Because the process requires a large input of electrical energy, a plausible first step of implementation would be for American nuclear-powered [[aircraft carrier]]s (the [[Nimitz-class aircraft carrier|Nimitz-class]] and the [[Gerald R. Ford-class aircraft carrier|Gerald R. Ford-class]]) to manufacture their own jet fuel.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.voanews.com/content/us-navy-lab-turns-seawater-into-fuel/1919512.html |title=US Navy Lab Turns Seawater Into Fuel |date=May 21, 2014 |last=Putic |first=George |newspaper=VOA News }}</ref> The U.S. Navy is expected to deploy the technology some time in the 2020s.<ref name=Tozer2014/>
== Demonstration projects and commercial development == A 250 kilowatt methane synthesis plant was constructed by the Center for Solar Energy and Hydrogen Research (ZSW) at [[Baden-Württemberg]] and the [[Fraunhofer Society]] in Germany and began operating in 2010. It is being upgraded to 10 megawatts, scheduled for completion in autumn, 2012.<ref>{{Cite web |author=Center for Solar Energy and Hydrogen Research Baden-Württemberg |date=2011 |title=Verbundprojekt 'Power-to-Gas' |language=German |publisher=''zsw-bw.de'' |url=http://www.zsw-bw.de/themen/brennstoffe-wasserstoff/power-to-gas.html |accessdate=September 9, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130216231811/http://www.zsw-bw.de/themen/brennstoffe-wasserstoff/power-to-gas.html |archivedate=February 16, 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Center for Solar Energy and Hydrogen Research |date=July 24, 2012 |title=Bundesumweltminister Altmaier und Ministerpräsident Kretschmann zeigen sich beeindruckt von Power-to-Gas-Anlage des ZSW |language=German |publisher=''zsw-bw.de'' |url=http://www.zsw-bw.de/infoportal/aktuelles/aktuelles-detail/hochrangige-politiker-lobten-zsw-innovationen.html |accessdate=September 9, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927082610/http://www.zsw-bw.de/infoportal/aktuelles/aktuelles-detail/hochrangige-politiker-lobten-zsw-innovationen.html |archivedate=September 27, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
The [[George Olah]] carbon dioxide recycling plant operated by [[Carbon Recycling International]] in [[Grindavík]], [[Iceland]] has been producing 2 million liters of [[methanol]] transportation fuel per year from flue exhaust of the [[Svartsengi Power Station]] since 2011.<ref>[http://www.chemicals-technology.com/projects/george-olah-renewable-methanol-plant-iceland/ "George Olah CO2 to Renewable Methanol Plant, Reykjanes, Iceland"] (Chemicals-Technology.com)</ref> It has the capacity to produce 5 million liters per year.<ref>[http://www.carbonrecycling.is/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=14&Itemid=8&lang=en "First Commercial Plant"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160204205612/http://www.carbonrecycling.is/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=14&Itemid=8&lang=en |date=February 4, 2016 }} (Carbon Recycling International)</ref>
[[Audi]] has constructed a carbon-neutral [[liquefied natural gas]] (LNG) plant in [[Werlte, Germany]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Okulski |first=Travis |title=Audi's Carbon Neutral E-Gas Is Real And They're Actually Making It |url=http://jalopnik.com/audis-carbon-neutral-e-gas-is-real-and-theyre-actuall-587518379 |accessdate=29 July 2013 |newspaper=Jalopnik (Gawker Media) |date=June 26, 2012}}</ref> The plant is intended to produce transportation fuel to offset LNG used in their [[Audi A3#A3 Sportback g-tron (2013-)|A3 Sportback g-tron]] automobiles, and can keep 2,800 metric tons of CO<sub>2</sub> out of the environment per year at its initial capacity.<ref>{{cite news |last=Rousseau |first=Steve |title=Audi's New E-Gas Plant Will Make Carbon-Neutral Fuel |url=http://www.popularmechanics.com/cars/news/auto-blog/audis-new-e-gas-plant-will-make-carbon-neutral-fuel-15627667 |accessdate=29 July 2013 |newspaper=Popular Mechanics |date=June 25, 2013}}</ref>
Commercial developments are taking place in [[Columbia, South Carolina]],<ref>[http://windfuels.com/ Doty Windfuels]</ref> [[Camarillo, California]],<ref>[http://www.coolplanetbiofuels.com/ CoolPlanet Energy Systems]</ref> and [[Darlington, England]].<ref>[http://airfuelsynthesis.com/ Air Fuel Synthesis, Ltd.]</ref> A demonstration project in [[Berkeley, California]] proposes synthesizing both fuels and [[food oil]]s from recovered flue gases.<ref>{{Cite web |author=[http://kiverdi.com/ Kiverdi, Inc.] |date=September 5, 2012 |title=Kiverdi Receives Energy Commission Funding for Its Pioneering Carbon Conversion Platform |type=press release |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/kiverdi-receives-energy-commission-funding-130000071.html |accessdate=September 12, 2012}}</ref>
== Greenhouse gas remediation == Carbon-neutral fuels can lead to greenhouse gas remediation because carbon dioxide gas would be reused to produce fuel instead of being released into the atmosphere. Capturing the carbon dioxide in flue gas emissions from power plants would eliminate their greenhouse gas emissions, although burning the fuel in vehicles would release that carbon because there is no economical way to capture those emissions.<ref name=Pearson2012/> This approach would reduce net carbon dioxide emission by about 50% if it were used on all fossil fuel power plants. Most [[coal power plant|coal]] and [[natural gas power plant]]s have been predicted to be economically retrofittable with [[carbon dioxide scrubber]]s for [[carbon capture]] to recycle flue exhaust or for [[carbon sequestration]].<ref>{{Cite report |last=DiPietro |first=Phil |last2=Nichols |first2=Chris |last3=Marquis |first3=Michael |date=January 2011 |title=''Coal-Fired Power Plants in the United States: Examination of the Costs of Retrofitting with CO<sub>2</sub> Capture Technology, Revision 3'' |publisher=National Energy Technology Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy |type=report NETL-402/102309 |docket=DOE contract DE-AC26-04NT41817 |url=http://www.netl.doe.gov/energy-analyses/pubs/GIS_CCS_retrofit.pdf |accessdate=September 7, 2012}}</ref><ref name=Socolow2011/><ref name=House2011/> Such recycling is expected to not only cost less than the excess [[economic impacts of climate change]] if it were not done, but also to pay for itself as global fuel [[economic demand|demand]] growth and [[peak oil]] shortages increase the price of [[petroleum]] and [[Fungibility|fungible]] [[natural gas]].<ref name=Goeppert2012/><ref name=Lackner2012/>
Capturing CO<sub>2</sub> directly from the air or extracting carbonic acid from seawater would also reduce the amount of carbon dioxide in the environment, and create a closed cycle of carbon to eliminate new carbon dioxide emissions.<ref name=Zeman2008 /> Use of these methods would eliminate the need for fossil fuels entirely, assuming that enough renewable energy could be generated to produce the fuel. Using synthetic hydrocarbons to produce synthetic materials such as plastics could result in permanent sequestration of carbon from the atmosphere.<ref name=Pearson2012 />
== Traditional fuels, methanol or ethanol == {{See also|Methanol economy}}
Some authorities have recommended producing [[methanol]] instead of traditional transportation fuels. It is a liquid at normal temperatures and can be toxic if ingested. Methanol has a higher [[octane rating]] than gasoline but a lower [[energy density]], and can be mixed with other fuels or used on its own. It may also be used in the production of more complex hydrocarbons and polymers. Direct methanol fuel cells have been developed by Caltech's [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] to convert methanol and oxygen into electricity.<ref name=Olah /> It is possible to convert methanol into gasoline, jet fuel or other hydrocarbons, but that requires additional energy and more complex production facilities.<ref name=Pearson2012 /> Methanol is slightly more corrosive than traditional fuels, requiring automobile modifications on the order of USD $100 each to use it.<ref name=Zeman2008/><ref name=Steinberg1995>{{Cite report |last=Steinberg |first=Meyer |date=August 1995 |title=''The Carnol Process for CO<sub>2</sub> Mitigation from Power Plants and the Transportation Sector |publisher=Department of Advanced Technology, Brookhaven National Laboratory |location=Upton, New York |type=informal report BNL–62110 |docket=(Prepared for the U.S. Department of Energy under Contract No. DE-AC02-76CH00016) |url=http://www.osti.gov/bridge/servlets/purl/100204-X2uZUC/webviewable/100204.pdf |accessdate=September 7, 2012}}</ref>
In 2016, a method using [[carbon spikes]], [[copper nanoparticle]]s and nitrogen that converts carbon dioxide to [[ethanol]] was developed.<ref name="CO2_to_ethanol" />
